bestBHT.bht: In this context, the conjunction used serves as a contrast to the previous sojourn in Peræa, directing our attention to Bethany, the village of Martha and Mary. It is mentioned that Mary and Martha were already well known from the current apostolic teaching. Bethany, situated at the east side of Mount Olivet, is specifically identified to distinguish it from another Bethany. This interruption in Jesus' retirement sets the stage for the powerful resurrection of Lazarus, a remarkable demonstration of Jesus' Divine power and a foreshadowing of future resurrection.

Bethany is designated as ‘the village of Martha and Mary,’ to distinguish it from that Bethany be-yond Jordan...
Mary and Martha are mentioned as already well known from the current apostolic teaching...

The identification of Mary with Mary Magdalene is a mere conjecture supported by no direct evidence, and opposed to the general tenor of the Gospels" (Westcott).

bhtAttempts.bht: In John 11:1, the conjunction used expresses a contrast to the sojourn in Peræa and brings attention to Bethany, the village of Martha and Mary. It is mentioned that Mary and Martha were well known from the current apostolic teaching. Bethany is specifically located at the east side of Mount Olivet and is distinguished from the other Bethany beyond Jordan. The interruption to Jesus' retirement is marked by the word now. The periphrastic imperfect active of ασθενεω is used to describe Lazarus' illness, indicating a sense of weakness. The identification of Mary with Mary Magdalene is not supported by direct evidence and goes against the general tenor of the Gospels. This verse sets the stage for the resurrection of Lazarus, a remarkable proof of Jesus' Divine power and a preview of future resurrection.

In this passage, the conjunction used contrasts the previous sojourn with the focus on Bethany, specifically the village of Martha and Mary. It is worth mentioning that Mary and Martha were already well known from apostolic teaching. Notably, Bethany is situated at the east side of Mount Olivet and is distinguished from another Bethany. The interruption to Jesus' retirement is marked by the word now. This sets the stage for the powerful resurrection of Lazarus, demonstrating Jesus' Divine power and foreshadowing our own future resurrection.

In this conjunction, there is a clear contrast to the sojourn in Peræa, directing our attention to Bethany, specifically the village of Martha and Mary. Mary and Martha are noted to be already well known from current apostolic teaching. Bethany is situated at the east side of Mount Olivet, distinguishing it from the other Bethany. This interruption to Jesus' retirement is significant, as it sets the stage for the remarkable resurrection of Lazarus, showcasing Jesus' Divine power and providing a glimpse of our own future resurrection.

The conjunction used in this context serves not only as a word of transition, but also implies a contrast to the previous sojourn in Peræa. It draws our attention to Bethany, specifically referred to as the village of Martha and Mary, distinguishing it from another Bethany beyond Jordan. Additionally, it is worth noting that Mary and Martha were already well known due to the current apostolic teaching. Bethany, located at the east side of Mount Olivet, serves as the backdrop for the powerful resurrection of Lazarus, a profound display of Jesus' Divine power and a glimpse of our own future resurrection.
